scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: In this collection are ca. 141 items, 1861 to 1876, which consist of mainly correspondence, with a few documents, pertaining to the Civil War between the United Statesand the Confederacy. The material relates specifically to the course of the war as seen by the Army of Northern Virginia.

John Cowper Granbery, a Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church, was born on December 5, 1829, in Norfolk, Virginia. He joined the Methodist Episcopal Churchat the age of fourteen, and two years later he matriculated at Randolph-Macon College, where he graduated in 1848. For the next thirteen years he served as a itinerant preacher and missionary. In the years immediately before the Civil War he served in these positions at the University of Virginia. He was a chaplain in the Confederate Armyfrom 1861-1865, and in 1875 was appointed acting professor of mental and moral philosophy and professor of practical theology in the Biblical department of Vanderbilt University, Nashville, Tennessee. In 1882 he was elected Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South. He was also appointed to the Board of Trustees of Vanderbilt Universityin 1882. He married Jennie Massiein 1858, who died a year later. He then married Ella Winstonin 1862.

John Cowper Granberystarts the period as an itinerant preacher and missionary at the University of Virginia. After the secession of the state of Virginiain early 1861, he volunteered for chaplain duty in the army. On July 12, 1861, he received his commission as chaplain to the 11th regiment, Army of Northern Virginia. Although in different regiments, he served in this division throughout the war.

The letters of February through May of 1861 deal with life at the University of Virginia, and the attitudes there toward the secession crisis. Different events of the period are described. The letters of July through October of the same year pertain to his joining the Army, and its preparations for war. Also discussed is the drudgery of camp life.

The letters of September 11 and 13, 1862, describe his being wounded and captured during the Seven Days Battle around Richmond, and of his regret of not being able to be with the Army during its invasion of Maryland. The letters of October and November describe the Army's situation as it camped at Winchester, Virginia.

The letters of December, 1862, describe the Fredericksburgcampaign. He describes the battle in detail, as he had an opportunity to observe it first hand from high ground. Also interesting is the letter of December 20, 1862, as he describes the interaction of Union and Confederate soldiers after the battle.

The letters of May 29 through July 15, 1863, describe the preparations for and the aftermath of the Gettysburgcampaign. The letters before the battle talk of the great strength and confidence of the army as it marched northward. The letter of July 8 describes the battle and its aftermath. Of particular interest is the description of the decimation of General [George Edward] Pickett's division, of which he is a member. The letters of August 1863 begin to describe the increased interest of the troops in religious activities. He also talks of his efforts to help increase this interest. The letter of September 10, 1863 ends the year's correspondence as he states that General James Longstreet's Corps would be going to Chattanooga, Tennessee, to reinforce General Braxton Bragg. General Pickett's Division was a part of this Corps.

Letters of March 21 through April 30, 1864 describe the army's limited action and increase of religious activity. The letter of May 6 describes the Battle of the Wilderness, and the letters of May 13 and 16 describe the Battle of Spotsylvaniaand its aftermath.

The letters of June 24, 1864 through March 9, 1865, pertain to the Union siege of Petersburg, Virginia. A letter of July 20 expresses his disappointment at the failure of Jubal Early's attempt at capturing Washington D.C.He is also worried over the replacement of General Joseph E. Johnstonwith General John Bell Hoodin the defense of Atlanta. The letter of January 10, 1865, talks of the daily rise in prices of articles, and the corresponding despondence of the people. He also talks of the House of Delegates' refusal of peace resolutions.

The letters of January through April 1865 speak of the scarcity of food and fuel experienced by the men in Petersburg. The letters of February 24 and 27 describe the situation in Petersburgand Richmonda month before the cities are abandoned.
The last letters of the war speak of the great need of food. There is no description of the Army of Northern Virginia's last stand, or surrender, at Appomattox, Virginia.

The eight letters of 1866, 1868, 1876, and 1878 describe the different Conferences of the Methodist Episcopal Churchthat Granbery attended during these years. There are also eleven letters written from his wife Ella to him during the Civil War. These pertain only to life at home without her husband and the problems of raising children during a war.
